üì¶ Kya CDN Pe Cache Hota Hai vs Kya Nahi?

‚úÖ CDN PE CACHE KARO
  • JavaScript bundles
  • CSS stylesheets
  • Images / Videos
  • Fonts
  • Static HTML pages
  • Public API responses (GET)
  • Product images (e-commerce)
‚ùå CDN PE CACHE MAT KARO
  • User-specific data (profiles)
  • Authentication tokens
  • Payment/financial data
  • Real-time data (stock prices)
  • POST/PUT/DELETE requests
  • Personalized content
  • Admin/private APIs

üí° CDN Invalidation: Jab content update ho toh CDN cache clear karna padta hai!

  • Versioned URLs: app.v2.3.js ‚Üí Deploy pe new version = new URL = auto fresh!
  • Cache Purge API: CloudFront/Cloudflare API se specific paths purge karo
  • Short TTL for dynamic: Frequently changing content = short TTL (60s)
üî¥ Redis Cache Layer ‚Äî How It Fits in the HLD

CDN static content handle karta hai. Par dynamic data (user profiles, sessions, feed) ke liye Redis Cache use hota hai ‚Äî ye DB ke aage baith ke guard karta hai!

‚Üí Race condition avoid karna hai! Delete simple + safe. Let next read populate fresh data.

üì¶ Kya Redis Mein Cache Karo vs Kya Nahi?

‚úÖ REDIS MEIN CACHE KARO
  • User sessions / JWT tokens
  • User profiles (read-heavy)
  • Feed / Timeline data
  • Product catalog (e-commerce)
  • Rate limiting counters
  • Leaderboards (Sorted Sets)
  • Shopping cart (temporary)
  • Config / Feature flags
‚ùå REDIS MEIN CACHE MAT KARO
  • Payment / Financial data
  • Data that changes every second
  • Large blobs (files, images)
  • Data requiring strong consistency
  • Regulatory / Audit trail data
  • Sensitive PII without encryption
  • Rarely accessed (long-tail) data
  • Data larger than RAM budget
‚öñÔ∏è ByteByteGo Cache + CDN Considerations

üìñ ByteByteGo Book Key Points ‚Äî Cache + CDN Design Considerations

1Ô∏è‚É£ When to Use Cache

Data frequently read but infrequently modified ho tab cache use karo. Cache volatile memory (RAM) mein rehta hai ‚Äî important data sirf database mein rakho, cache mein nahi!

"Cache is NOT a database. It can be lost anytime. Always have DB as source of truth!"

2Ô∏è‚É£ Expiration Policy (TTL)

TTL bahut short? ‚Üí Cache se baar baar data expire hoga, DB pe load badhega (defeats the purpose!)

TTL bahut long? ‚Üí Stale data serve hoga, users ko purana data dikhega!

‚úÖ Sweet spot: Depends on use case. User profiles = 1hr, Feed = 5min, Session = 30min

3Ô∏è‚É£ Consistency ‚Äî DB aur Cache Sync

Database aur cache mein data inconsistent ho sakta hai kyunki dono update ek atomic operation mein nahi hota. Ye distributed systems mein inevitable hai.

Facebook paper: "Scaling Memcache at Facebook" ‚Äî eventual consistency acceptable for most social features!

4Ô∏è‚É£ Mitigating Failures ‚Äî Single Cache ‚â† SPOF

Single cache server = Single Point of Failure! Agar Redis crash ho toh poora system slow ho jayega.

  • Multiple cache servers across different data centers
  • Redis Sentinel / Cluster for auto-failover
  • Overprovision memory to handle traffic spikes
5Ô∏è‚É£ Eviction Policy

Cache full ho jaye toh kya remove karein?

LRU (Least Recently Used) = Most popular choice! Jo data sabse lamba time se access nahi hua, use hataao.

Other options: LFU (frequency-based), FIFO (first-in-first-out), Random

6Ô∏è‚É£ CDN Considerations from the Book
  • Cost: CDN third-party providers chalate hain ‚Äî data transfer in/out ka cost hota hai. Infrequently used assets CDN se hataao!
  • Setting TTL: Too long = stale, Too short = origin pe repeated hits. Content type ke hisaab se set karo.
  • CDN Fallback: CDN down ho toh clients directly origin server se fetch kar sakein ‚Äî resilient design!
  • Invalidating files: CDN API se object invalidate karo ya versioning use karo (e.g., image_v2.png)
üèÜ Complete HLD Summary ‚Äî 7 Golden Rules
‚ö†Ô∏è BEFORE (Figure 1-6 Only):
graph LR U1["üë§ Users"] --> LB1["‚öñÔ∏è LB"] --> API_B["üñ•Ô∏è API"] --> DB1[("üêò DB + Replicas")] style U1 fill:#a855f7,color:#fff,stroke:#a855f7 style LB1 fill:#f59e0b,color:#000,stroke:#f59e0b style API_B fill:#6366f1,color:#fff,stroke:#6366f1 style DB1 fill:#ef4444,color:#fff,stroke:#ef4444

‚ö†Ô∏è Every request hits DB. Static from origin.

‚úÖ AFTER (Evolved with Cache + CDN):
graph LR U2["üë§ Users"] --> CDN2["üåê CDN
L1"] --> LB2["‚öñÔ∏è LB"] --> API_A["üñ•Ô∏è API"] --> REDIS2["üî¥ Redis
L2"] --> DB2[("üêò DB + Replicas")] style U2 fill:#a855f7,color:#fff,stroke:#a855f7 style CDN2 fill:#06b6d4,color:#000,stroke:#06b6d4 style LB2 fill:#f59e0b,color:#000,stroke:#f59e0b style API_A fill:#6366f1,color:#fff,stroke:#6366f1 style REDIS2 fill:#ef4444,color:#fff,stroke:#ef4444 style DB2 fill:#22c55e,color:#000,stroke:#22c55e

‚úÖ 80-95% reads from cache. Static from CDN edge.

üîë 7 GOLDEN RULES:
  1. Cache is NOT a database ‚Äî can be lost, always have DB!
  2. CDN for STATIC, Redis for DYNAMIC ‚Äî clear separation!
  3. TTL wisely set karo ‚Äî too short = useless, too long = stale
  4. Cache-Aside = safest default for most read-heavy apps
  5. On WRITE ‚Üí Update DB first, then invalidate (DEL) cache
  6. Redis Cluster/Sentinel for HA ‚Äî single cache = SPOF!
  7. Monitor hit rate ‚Äî below 60%? Cache strategy review karo!

üìñ ByteByteGo Takeaway:

"The fastest database query is the one you never have to make.
The fastest network request is the one served from the edge.
That's the power of Cache + CDN." üöÄ

‚ö†Ô∏è

Single Point of Failure (SPOF)

üí• SPOF Kya Hai?

Single Point of Failure (SPOF) = Wo ek component jo fail hone pe poora system fail ho jaye!

High availability systems mein SPOF hona = BAD NEWS!

üõ°Ô∏è SPOF Se Kaise Bachein? - Redundancy!

üîß Component Level
  • Multiple power supplies
  • Multiple hard drives (RAID)
  • Redundant network cards
  • Spare parts ready
üñ•Ô∏è System Level
  • Server clusters
  • Load balancers
  • Standby servers (failover)
  • Database replicas
üåç Site Level
  • Multiple data centers
  • Geographic distribution
  • DR (Disaster Recovery) sites
  • Cloud multi-region deployment

üíª Computing Mein SPOF Examples

  • Single Database Server: Use replicas!
  • Single Load Balancer: Use multiple LBs with failover
  • Single Data Center: Multi-region deployment
  • Single DNS Provider: Secondary DNS setup
  • Single Cloud Provider: Multi-cloud strategy (but adds complexity)

üåê Internet Ka Design - No SPOF!

Paul Baran aur Donald Davies ne packet switching develop kiya - Internet ka foundation!

  • Multiple paths exist between any two points
  • Packets can "route around" damaged paths
  • Single node failure se communication nahi rukti

üë®‚Äçüíª Software Engineering Mein

Bottleneck = Jab ek component ki capacity se poora system limit ho jaye

Example: Code jo parallel ho sakta hai but sequential run ho raha hai

Solution: Performance profiling ‚Üí Hot spots identify karo ‚Üí Optimize!

üîí Security Mein SPOF

Ek vulnerability = poora system compromise!

  • User error sabse common SPOF hai - phishing attacks!
  • Defense in depth - multiple security layers
  • Zero trust architecture
üìò

Scaling Memcache at Facebook

üîµ Facebook's Caching Architecture

Facebook handles billions of requests per second!

Trillions of items cached - 1 billion+ users serve karte hain

üéØ Problem Statement

Web services mein responsiveness essential hai. Speed drives:

  • User Engagement ‚Üí Users fast experience chahte hain
  • Revenue ‚Üí Slow = users leave = money loss

üìä Architecture Pattern

Typical Web Stack:

  • Database split across servers
  • Caches sit in front for scaling reads
  • Over time, caches become primary data store (de facto)

‚ö†Ô∏è Challenges at Scale

  • Consistency: Cache aur database sync kaise rakho?
  • Failure Handling: Cache fail ho toh kya?
  • Replication: Multiple data centers pe cache?
  • Load Balancing: Cache servers pe load distribute

üîß Facebook's Solutions

Software Improvements

Memcached client/server optimizations

Cache-DB Coordination

Consistency & replication management

Failover Tuning

Operational needs ke liye optimized

üí° Key Insights

Trade-off Alert: Facebook ne strong consistency sacrifice ki for:

  • ‚úÖ Better Performance
  • ‚úÖ Higher Availability
  • ‚úÖ Simpler Architecture

"In practice, performance, availability, and simplicity often outweigh the benefits of precise semantics."

‚ö†Ô∏è Imprecise Semantics

  • Memcached data lose ya evict kar sakta hai without notice
  • Replication aur cache invalidation transactional nahi
  • Isolation limited hai
  • Failure handling workload dependent hai

But it works! Strong semantics zaroori nahi hain large-scale web services ke liye - Facebook proved it.

‚öñÔ∏è

Load Balancing - Traffic Distribution

üîÄ Load Balancer Kya Hai?

Load Balancer incoming traffic ko multiple backend servers mein distribute karta hai for:

  • High Availability: Agar ek server down ho toh doosre serve karte hain
  • Scalability: More servers add karke capacity increase karo
  • Performance: Load evenly distribute = faster response

üìä Load Balancing Algorithms:

Algorithm How It Works Best For
Round Robin Requests rotate among servers in order Equal capacity servers
Weighted Round Robin More powerful servers ko zyada requests Mixed server capacities
Least Connections Sabse kam active connections wale server pe bhejo Long-lived connections
IP Hash Client IP ka hash ‚Üí consistent server Session persistence
Least Response Time Fastest responding server choose karo Performance-critical apps

üîß Types of Load Balancers:

Layer 4 (Transport)

TCP/UDP level pe route karta hai

  • Fast - packet inspection minimal
  • Can't see HTTP content
  • AWS NLB, HAProxy (TCP mode)
Layer 7 (Application)

HTTP headers, URLs, cookies dekh sakta hai

  • Smart routing (path-based, header-based)
  • SSL termination
  • AWS ALB, Nginx, Envoy

‚òÅÔ∏è AWS Load Balancers:

ALB

Application Load Balancer

HTTP/HTTPS, path routing

NLB

Network Load Balancer

TCP/UDP, ultra-low latency

CLB

Classic Load Balancer

Legacy, both L4 & L7

GWLB

Gateway Load Balancer

Virtual appliances

üéØ Interview Questions - Load Balancing

Q: "Layer 4 vs Layer 7 Load Balancer - kab kya use karoge?"

Answer:

  • Layer 4 (L4): TCP/UDP level routing - ultra-fast, millions of connections, gaming servers, real-time apps
  • Layer 7 (L7): HTTP level routing - URL path based routing, A/B testing, canary deployments, API versioning
  • Example: /api/v1/* ‚Üí Service A, /api/v2/* ‚Üí Service B (L7 needed)
  • Example: High-frequency trading - L4 kyunki every microsecond counts

Q: "Load Balancer khud SPOF ban jaye toh?"

Answer: Multiple techniques use karein:

  • Active-Passive: Primary LB down ‚Üí Secondary automatically takeover (HAProxy + Keepalived)
  • Active-Active: Multiple LBs simultaneously traffic handle karein (DNS round robin)
  • Cloud LBs: AWS ALB/NLB already highly available - multiple AZs mein deployed
  • DNS Failover: Route 53 health checks ‚Üí healthy LB pe redirect

Q: "10 million concurrent users handle karne ke liye LB strategy?"

Answer: Multi-tier architecture:

  • Tier 1 - DNS: GeoDNS (Route 53) ‚Üí nearest region route
  • Tier 2 - Edge: CDN (CloudFront) static content serve kare
  • Tier 3 - Global LB: AWS Global Accelerator / anycast routing
  • Tier 4 - Regional LB: NLB (L4) + ALB (L7) cascade
  • Scaling: Auto Scaling Groups + target tracking policies

Netflix pattern: AWS + Open Connect CDN appliances at ISPs

üè¢ Real-World Load Balancing

üîÑ Google's Maglev

Type: Software L4 Load Balancer

  • 10Gbps per machine throughput
  • Consistent hashing for connection affinity
  • ECMP for horizontal scaling
üé≠ Facebook's Katran

Type: XDP-based L4 LB

  • 10M+ packets/sec per core
  • eBPF/XDP for kernel bypass
  • Consistent hashing + connection tracking
üåê Cloudflare's Unimog

Type: L4 Edge Load Balancer

  • Anycast + BGP announcements
  • Weighted ECMP for traffic steering
  • Near-instant failover
üîó

Sticky Sessions - Load Balancer Magic

‚öñÔ∏è What is Session Affinity?

Sticky Sessions (Session Affinity) ensure karti hain ki ek user ki saari requests same backend server pe jaayein.

ü§î Kyun Chahiye?

Agar user ka session data (cart, login) local server memory mein store hai, toh doosre server pe request jaane se session lost ho jayega!

üõ†Ô∏è Implementation Methods:

üç™ Cookie-Based

Load balancer ek special cookie set karta hai (AWSALB, JSESSIONID)

Most common approach

üåê IP-Based

Client IP ka hash use karke server select karo

Breaks with NAT/proxies

üîê Application-level

Session ID route karke specific server pe bhejo

More control, more complexity

‚ö†Ô∏è Drawbacks:

  • Uneven Load: Some servers zyada loaded ho sakte hain
  • Server Failure: Agar sticky server crash ho toh user ka session lost
  • Scaling Issues: New servers ko traffic kam milta hai

‚úÖ Better Alternative: External Session Store

Redis ya Memcached mein sessions store karo - ab koi bhi server request handle kar sakta hai!

Stateless servers = easier scaling!

üåê

CDN & Dynamic Content Delivery

‚òÅÔ∏è Amazon CloudFront

CDN (Content Delivery Network) globally distributed servers ka network hai jo content users ke paas serve karta hai.

üéØ Dynamic Content Delivery Use Cases

üîå

APIs & IoT

Application development, telemetry

üõí

E-commerce

Retail, travel bookings

üì∫

Advertising

Ad serving, targeting

üì∞

News & Sports

Live updates, weather

üì±

Mobile Apps

App content delivery

üí° CDN Benefits

  • Lower Latency: Content users ke geographically paas serve hota hai
  • Higher Availability: Distributed = more resilient
  • Reduced Origin Load: Origin server pe load kam
  • Cost Savings: Bandwidth costs kam

8 Scaling Strategies - Amazon, Netflix, Uber Style!

üöÄ Ye Giants Kaise Scale Karte Hain?

ü§î Amazon, Netflix, Uber mein kya common hai?

They are EXTREMELY GOOD at SCALING! üìà

Ye 8 strategies use karke millions of users ko serve karte hain!

1Ô∏è‚É£ Stateless Services

Server pe koi state store nahi! State external store (Redis, DB) mein rakho.

Benefit: Koi bhi server request handle kar sakta hai - easy horizontal scaling!

‚úÖ Session = Redis, JWT tokens use karo

2Ô∏è‚É£ Horizontal Scaling

More machines add karo, bigger machine nahi!

Vertical: 1 powerful server (limited)
Horizontal: 100 normal servers (unlimited growth!)

üìà Netflix: 1000s of instances pe run hota hai

3Ô∏è‚É£ Load Balancing

Traffic evenly distribute karo across servers!

Algorithms: Round Robin, Least Connections, IP Hash, Weighted

üîÑ AWS ALB, Nginx, HAProxy use karo

4Ô∏è‚É£ Auto Scaling

Traffic badhe to automatically new servers spawn ho!

Triggers: CPU > 70%, Memory > 80%, Request count, Queue length

‚ö° Black Friday sale? Auto-scale handles it!

5Ô∏è‚É£ Caching

Frequently accessed data memory mein rakho!

Layers: Browser ‚Üí CDN ‚Üí API Cache ‚Üí DB Cache

üöÄ Redis, Memcached - DB calls 100x reduce!

6Ô∏è‚É£ Database Replication

Master-Slave setup: Writes Master pe, Reads Slaves pe!

Types: Sync (strong consistency), Async (better performance)

üìö Read replicas: 10x read capacity increase!

7Ô∏è‚É£ Database Sharding

Data partition karo across multiple databases!

Strategies: Hash-based, Range-based, Geographic

üîÄ Uber: City-wise sharding karta hai!

8Ô∏è‚É£ Async Processing

Heavy tasks queue mein daalo, response immediately do!

Tools: RabbitMQ, Kafka, SQS, Redis Queue

üìß Email send? Queue it! User wait nahi karega.

üéØ Strategy Selection Quick Guide:

Problem Solution
Too many requests Horizontal Scaling + Load Balancing
Database slow Caching + Read Replicas
Traffic spikes Auto Scaling
Too much data Sharding
Slow responses Async Processing + Queues

üéØ Interview Questions - System Scaling

Q: "Design a system that can handle 1 million concurrent users"

Answer Framework (SNAKE method):

  1. Scenario: Read-heavy ya write-heavy? What's the QPS?
  2. Necessary: Requirements clarify karo - latency, availability targets
  3. Application: Stateless services, horizontal scaling
  4. Kernels: Core components - CDN, Load Balancer, Cache layer, DB sharding
  5. Evolution: Start simple, scale incrementally

Typical setup: 50 app servers + 5 DB replicas + Redis cluster + CDN = ~1M users

Q: "Database sharding strategy kaise decide karoge?"

Answer:

  • Hash-based: user_id % num_shards ‚Üí even distribution, but rebalancing hard
  • Range-based: User 1-1M ‚Üí Shard1, 1M-2M ‚Üí Shard2 ‚Üí hotspots possible
  • Directory/Lookup: Mapping table maintain karo ‚Üí flexible but extra lookup
  • Geographic: Region-wise sharding ‚Üí great for latency, data locality

Pro Tip: Consistent hashing use karo for easier resharding - Vitess, CockroachDB do this automatically

Q: "Vertical vs Horizontal scaling - tradeoffs explain karo"

Aspect Vertical Horizontal
Cost Expensive (bigger machines) Cheaper (commodity hardware)
Limit Physical limit hai Virtually unlimited
Downtime Upgrade ke liye downtime Zero downtime possible
Complexity Simple Distributed systems complexity

Q: "Auto-scaling policies kaise configure karoge?"

Answer:

  • Target Tracking: "Keep CPU at 50%" - simplest, AWS recommended
  • Step Scaling: CPU 50-70% ‚Üí add 1, 70-90% ‚Üí add 3, >90% ‚Üí add 5
  • Predictive: ML-based, traffic patterns predict karke pre-scale
  • Custom Metrics: Queue depth, request latency-based scaling

Important: Cooldown period set karo (300 sec) to prevent thrashing. Scale out fast, scale in slow!

üî¢

Big Endian vs Little Endian

üíæ Byte Ordering Kya Hai?

Microprocessors memory mein bytes store karne ke liye do different methods use karte hain - isko "byte ordering" ya "endianness" kehte hain.

üìò Little Endian

Least Significant Byte (LSB) pehle store hota hai, phir Most Significant Byte.

Number: 0x12345678

Memory: [78] [56] [34] [12]

Address: Low ‚Üí High

Used by: Intel x86, AMD, ARM (default)

üìï Big Endian

Most Significant Byte (MSB) pehle store hota hai, phir Least Significant.

Number: 0x12345678

Memory: [12] [34] [56] [78]

Address: Low ‚Üí High

Used by: Network protocols, PowerPC, Motorola 68k

‚ö†Ô∏è Kyun Important Hai?

  • Network Communication: Network "Big Endian" use karti hai (Network Byte Order)
  • File Formats: Different formats different endianness use karte hain
  • Cross-Platform: Different systems ke beech data transfer mein byte order handle karna zaroori

Tip: C mein htons(), ntohl() functions byte order convert karte hain!

üìù

Event Sourcing - Events Hi Source of Truth

üîÑ Event Sourcing Kya Hai?

Traditional: State Store Karo

‚¨áÔ∏è

Event Sourcing: Events Store Karo!

Event sourcing mein hum current state store nahi karte, instead sequence of events store karte hain jo state ko change karte hain. Event store is the source of truth!

üè¢ Real-World Examples:

üì∞ New York Times

Har article, image, byline since 1851 event store mein!

Raw data ‚Üí Denormalized views ‚Üí ElasticSearch nodes

üîÑ CDC (Change Data Capture)

Tables se data pull ‚Üí Events mein transform ‚Üí Kafka pe push

Other services consume from Kafka

üõí Microservices

Shopping cart service ‚Üí Events generate karta hai

Events: ItemAdded, ItemRemoved, CheckoutStarted

‚úÖ Benefits:

  • Complete Audit Trail: Har change ka history available hai
  • Time Travel: Any point in time ka state recreate kar sakte ho
  • Debug Easily: Exact sequence of events dekh sakte ho
  • Event Replay: New projections/views create karne ke liye replay kar sakte ho

UDP Protocol - Speed Over Reliability

‚ö° Top 4 UDP Use Cases

UDP (User Datagram Protocol) TCP se simple, fast, aur low overhead hai. Jab speed > reliability matter kare, tab UDP use karo!

üìπ

VoIP, Video Conferencing mein thoda packet loss tolerable hai

Zoom, Teams, Google Meet

üåê

Fast, lightweight queries - mostly single packet mein response

TCP only for large responses

üìä

Market Data Multicast

Low-latency trading mein multiple recipients ko simultaneously data

Stock exchanges, HFT

üì±

IoT Devices

Small packets, frequent communication

Sensors, Smart Home

üîÑ TCP vs UDP:

Feature TCP UDP
Connection Connection-oriented (3-way handshake) Connectionless
Reliability Guaranteed delivery Best effort (may lose packets)
Speed Slower (overhead) Faster (minimal overhead)
Use Case Web, Email, File Transfer Streaming, Gaming, DNS

üîë Important Cookie Attributes:

Name/Value

Actual data stored

Domain

Kaunsi site pe send karna hai

Secure

Only HTTPS pe bhejo

HttpOnly

JavaScript access nahi kar sakti

SameSite

Cross-site request control

Expires/Max-Age

Kab tak valid hai

üõ°Ô∏è Security Best Practices:

  • HttpOnly: XSS attacks se bachao - JS access block
  • Secure: HTTPS pe hi cookies bhejo
  • SameSite=Strict: CSRF protection
  • Short Expiry: Session cookies use karo jahan possible

Apache Kafka 101 - The Ultimate Guide

üöÄ Kafka Kya Hai?

Distributed Event Store + Streaming Platform

LinkedIn ne banaya, ab Netflix, Uber, Airbnb sab use karte hain!

üì¶ 8 Kafka Fundamentals:

1 Messages

Basic unit of data - like a row in table

Headers + Key + Value

2 Topics & Partitions

Topic = folder, Partitions = parallel processing

Each partition is an ordered log

3 Producer

Messages create, batch, aur send karta hai

Partitions across balance karta hai

4 Consumer Group

Multiple consumers mil ke messages read karte hain

Parallel consumption enable!

5 Broker

Server jo messages store aur serve karta hai

Multiple brokers = Cluster

6 Replication

Partitions replicate across brokers

High availability + fault tolerance

üéØ Use Cases:

üìä Log Analysis üîÑ Data Streaming üìù Change Data Capture üìà System Monitoring üîî Event-Driven Architecture

‚úÖ Key Advantages:

  • Disk-based retention: Messages disk pe store hote hain, RAM nahi
  • Multiple producers/consumers: Decoupled architecture
  • High scalability: Partitions add karke scale karo
  • Durability: Replication ensures data safety

üéØ Interview Questions - Apache Kafka

Q: "Kafka mein message ordering kaise guarantee hoti hai?"

Answer: Kafka ordering partition level pe guarantee karta hai:

  • Same partition mein messages order preserved rehta hai
  • Multiple partitions mein global order nahi - sirf partition-local order
  • Strategy: Related messages ko same partition mein bhejo (partition key use karo)
  • Example: User_123 ke saare orders same partition mein ‚Üí order sequence maintain

Tip: max.in.flight.requests.per.connection=1 for strict ordering (with some throughput tradeoff)

Q: "Exactly-once delivery Kafka mein possible hai?"

Answer: Haan, Kafka 0.11+ se exactly-once semantics support karta hai:

  • Idempotent Producer: enable.idempotence=true ‚Üí duplicate messages avoid
  • Transactions: transactional.id set karo ‚Üí atomic writes across partitions
  • Consumer: read_committed isolation level use karo

Caveat: Exactly-once sirf Kafka-to-Kafka scenarios mein guaranteed. External systems ke saath idempotent consumers design karo!

Q: "Consumer lag detect aur handle kaise karoge?"

Answer: Consumer lag = difference between latest offset aur consumer's current offset:

  • Monitoring: kafka-consumer-groups.sh --describe, Burrow, Kafka Exporter + Prometheus
  • Alerting: Lag > threshold ‚Üí PagerDuty alert
  • Fix Options:
    • Consumers scale karo (more instances in consumer group)
    • Partitions badhao (if consumer count < partition count)
    • Processing optimize karo (batch processing, async I/O)

Q: "Kafka vs RabbitMQ vs SQS - kab kya use karoge?"

Use Case Best Choice
High-throughput streaming, log aggregation Kafka
Complex routing, priority queues RabbitMQ
Simple task queues, AWS ecosystem SQS
Event replay, audit logs Kafka (log retention)

üè¢ Kafka at Scale - Real Companies

üíº LinkedIn

Kafka create kiya, 7 trillion messages/day process karte hain

Activity tracking, metrics, news feed

üé¨ Netflix

500B+ events/day - real-time personalization

Keystone pipeline for all internal events

üê¶ Twitter

400B+ events/day across 1000s of topics

User interactions, logging, analytics

gRPC - High Performance RPC

‚ö° gRPC Kya Hai?

gRPC Google ka high-performance, open-source RPC (Remote Procedure Call) framework hai. Microservices ke beech efficient communication ke liye best!

üîë Key Features:

üìÑ Protocol Buffers

Binary serialization - JSON/XML se chota aur faster!

.proto files define karo

üåê HTTP/2 Transport

Multiplexing, header compression, bidirectional streaming

Single connection pe multiple requests

üîß Multi-Language

Go, Java, Python, Node.js, C++, Rust...

Auto-generate client/server code

üîÑ Streaming

Unary, Server-streaming, Client-streaming, Bidirectional

Real-time data exchange

üìä REST vs gRPC:

Aspect REST gRPC
Protocol HTTP/1.1 HTTP/2
Format JSON/XML (text) Protocol Buffers (binary)
Speed Slower Faster (7-10x)
Browser Support Excellent Limited (grpc-web)

üéØ Interview Questions - gRPC

Q: "REST API se gRPC pe migrate kyun karoge?"

Answer: Migration consider karo jab:

  • High throughput: Millions of requests/sec - protobuf 7-10x faster than JSON
  • Microservices: Service-to-service communication mein REST overhead zyada
  • Bi-directional streaming: Real-time features jaise chat, notifications
  • Strong typing: .proto files = compile-time type safety

Note: Browser-facing APIs ke liye REST/GraphQL better - gRPC-web limited hai

Q: "gRPC mein streaming types explain karo"

Answer: 4 types of gRPC calls:

Unary

1 request ‚Üí 1 response (like REST)

Server Streaming

1 request ‚Üí N responses (stock prices)

Client Streaming

N requests ‚Üí 1 response (file upload)

Bidirectional

N requests ‚Üî N responses (chat)

Q: "gRPC errors aur timeouts kaise handle karoge?"

Answer:

  • Status Codes: gRPC has own codes (OK, CANCELLED, DEADLINE_EXCEEDED, NOT_FOUND, etc.)
  • Deadline: Har call pe deadline set karo - cascade failures avoid karne ke liye
  • Retry Policy: Exponential backoff with jitter configure karo
  • Circuit Breaker: Service mesh (Istio) ya library level pe implement karo

Best Practice: Always propagate deadlines across service calls

üè¢ gRPC in Production

üî∑ Google

gRPC create kiya - 10 billion+ RPC calls/sec internally

All internal services gRPC use karte hain

üé¨ Netflix

Hybrid approach - gRPC + GraphQL

Internal: gRPC, External: REST/GraphQL

üöó Uber

2000+ microservices gRPC se communicate

Rider-Driver matching, pricing engine

üîî

Polling vs Webhooks - Real-time Data Ka Funda

üîÑ Data Fetch Karne Ke 2 Tarike

ü§î External service se data kaise lo?

Do approaches: Tu poochta reh (Polling) ya wo bata dega (Webhooks)!

üîÑ Polling

"Do you have something new for me?"

Kaise kaam karta hai:

  • Fixed intervals pe check karo
  • Har 5 seconds: "Kuch naya hai?"
  • Repeat... repeat... repeat...

‚úÖ Pros:

  • Simple to implement
  • Full control on timing
  • No need for callback endpoint

‚ùå Cons:

  • Resource-intensive (waste API calls)
  • Not real-time (delay hota hai)
  • High server load

üîî Webhooks

"I'll notify you when something happens!"

Kaise kaam karta hai:

  • Callback URL register karo
  • Event hone pe ‚Üí Service tujhe call karega
  • Instant notification!

‚úÖ Pros:

  • Real-time updates
  • Efficient (no wasted calls)
  • Less server load

‚ùå Cons:

  • Need public endpoint
  • Missed notifications (network issues)
  • Retry mechanism chahiye

üéØ Kab Kya Use Karein?

Scenario Choice Why?
Payment notifications Webhooks Instant confirmation needed
Stock prices Polling Continuous updates, no webhooks available
GitHub actions Webhooks Trigger on push/PR events
Behind firewall Polling No public endpoint possible
üí° Real-World Examples:

Stripe: Payment success ‚Üí Webhook to your server ‚Üí Update order status

Twilio: SMS received ‚Üí Webhook ‚Üí Process message

Slack: Message posted ‚Üí Webhook ‚Üí Trigger bot action

üî∑

GraphQL - Modern API Query Language

üìä GraphQL Kya Hai?

GraphQL = "Graph Query Language"

Meta (Facebook) ne 2012 mein internally develop kiya, 2015 mein public release

GraphQL ek query language hai APIs ke liye. Clients exactly wahi data request kar sakte hain jo chahiye - no more, no less!

üÜö REST vs GraphQL

REST Problems üò´
  • Over-fetching: Extra data aata hai jo nahi chahiye
  • Under-fetching: Multiple endpoints hit karne padte
  • Multiple calls: /users, /posts, /comments alag alag
GraphQL Solutions üéâ
  • Precise data: Sirf wahi lo jo chahiye
  • Single endpoint: /graphql se sab kuch
  • One request: Nested data ek call mein

üìù GraphQL Operations:

üìñ

Query

Data fetch karo (READ)

‚úèÔ∏è

Mutation

Data modify karo (CUD)

üîî

Subscription

Real-time updates

üíª Example Query:

query

user(id: "123") {

name

email

posts {

title

likes

}

}

// Single request mein user + posts! üöÄ

‚úÖ Benefits:

  • Efficient data fetching
  • Strong type system
  • Self-documenting (introspection)
  • Great for microservices

‚ùå Challenges:

  • Complex to implement
  • Caching difficult
  • N+1 query problem
  • Over-fetching on server

üéØ Interview Questions - GraphQL

Q: "GraphQL mein N+1 problem kya hai aur kaise solve karoge?"

Answer: N+1 problem tab hota hai jab nested data fetch karte ho:

  • 1 query for fetching users + N queries for each user's posts = N+1 queries!
  • Solution - DataLoader: Batching + Caching pattern
    • Batch: Multiple IDs collect karo, ek query mein fetch karo
    • Cache: Same request cycle mein repeated calls avoid karo

Facebook ne DataLoader pattern develop kiya isi ke liye!

Q: "GraphQL vs REST - kab GraphQL better hai?"

GraphQL Choose Karo Jab:
  • Multiple clients (web, mobile, IoT)
  • Complex, nested data structures
  • Rapidly evolving APIs
  • Mobile apps (bandwidth sensitive)
REST Choose Karo Jab:
  • Simple CRUD operations
  • HTTP caching leverage karna hai
  • File uploads primary use case
  • Team GraphQL mein new hai

Q: "GraphQL security concerns kya hain?"

Answer: GraphQL specific vulnerabilities:

  • Query Depth Attack: Deeply nested queries server ko overwhelm kar sakte hain ‚Üí Query depth limiting set karo
  • Query Complexity: Heavy queries ‚Üí Complexity scoring + limits
  • Introspection Abuse: Schema expose hota hai ‚Üí Production mein disable karo
  • Batching Attacks: Multiple queries ek request mein ‚Üí Rate limit per operation, not per request

Tools: graphql-cost-analysis, graphql-depth-limit, persisted queries

üè¢ GraphQL at Scale

üìò Facebook/Meta

GraphQL inventors - Mobile apps ke liye develop kiya. Relay framework bhi unka hai.

üõí Shopify

Storefront API puri GraphQL based hai - e-commerce clients ke liye perfect.

üêô GitHub

GitHub API v4 is GraphQL - complex repository data efficiently fetch karo.

API vs SDK - Kya Farak Hai?

ü§î API aur SDK mein Difference

üîå API (Application Programming Interface)

Ek waiter ki tarah - orders le aur serve kare!

Kya hai?

Rules & protocols jo software components ko communicate karne dete hain

  • Endpoints, Requests, Responses define karta hai
  • Data exchange enable karta hai
  • Platform independent
  • Example: Twitter API, Stripe API

üì¶ SDK (Software Development Kit)

Poora toolkit - hammer, screwdriver, sab kuch!

Kya hai?

Complete package - libraries, tools, docs, sample code

  • Higher-level abstractions provide karta hai
  • Platform-specific optimization
  • Pre-built functions include
  • Example: iOS SDK, Android SDK, AWS SDK

üìä Quick Comparison:

Aspect API SDK
What it is Interface/Contract Complete Toolkit
Contains Endpoints, Docs Libraries, Tools, Code
Platform Language Agnostic Platform Specific
Complexity Lower level Higher level abstractions
üí° Simple Analogy:

API: Restaurant menu - you order what you want, kitchen (server) prepares it

SDK: Complete cooking kit - ingredients, recipes, utensils - you cook yourself!

üîê

SSH - Secure Shell Protocol

üîí SSH Kaise Kaam Karta Hai?

SSH (Secure Shell) unsecured network pe remote machines se securely connect karne ke liye use hota hai. Encryption, authentication, aur data transfer provide karta hai.

üèóÔ∏è SSH-2 ke 3 Layers:

1
Transport Layer

Encryption + Integrity + Data Protection

Algorithms: AES, ChaCha20, SHA-256

2
Authentication Layer

Client identity verify karta hai

Methods: Password, Public Key, Keyboard-interactive

3
Connection Layer

Multiple logical channels multiplex karta hai

Port forwarding, X11 forwarding, shell sessions

üîë Key-Based Authentication:

Why better than passwords?

  • No password over network = can't be intercepted
  • Private key never leaves your machine
  • Passphrase protection for extra security

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

üîÑ

Reverse Proxy vs API Gateway vs Load Balancer

ü¶∏ Three Superheroes of Web Architecture

üêù Modern websites are like busy beehives!

Ye teen tools manage karte hain sab kuch smoothly!

üïµÔ∏è Reverse Proxy - The Identity Changer

Kaam: Servers ko hide karo, requests secretly fetch karo!

  • Anonymity: Backend servers ka IP hide
  • Security: DDoS protection, WAF
  • SSL Termination: HTTPS handle karo
  • Caching: Static content cache

üéØ Perfect for: Cyber-attacks se protection, sensitive websites!

Tools: Nginx, HAProxy, Varnish

üìÆ API Gateway - The Postman

Kaam: Requests ko sahi services tak deliver karo!

  • Routing: Request ‚Üí Right microservice
  • Authentication: API keys, JWT validate
  • Rate Limiting: Traffic control
  • Transformation: Request/Response modify

üéØ Perfect for: Microservices architecture!

Tools: Kong, AWS API Gateway, Apigee

üö¶ Load Balancer - The Traffic Cop

Kaam: Traffic evenly distribute karo across servers!

  • Distribution: Traffic split karo
  • Health Checks: Unhealthy servers avoid
  • High Availability: No single point of failure
  • Scalability: Add/remove servers easily

üéØ Perfect for: High traffic websites!

Tools: AWS ALB/NLB, Nginx, F5

üìä Quick Comparison:

Feature Reverse Proxy API Gateway Load Balancer
Primary Purpose Hide servers API management Distribute traffic
Caching ‚úÖ Yes ‚úÖ Yes ‚ùå No
Auth/Rate Limiting Basic ‚úÖ Advanced ‚ùå No
Health Checks ‚ùå No ‚úÖ Yes ‚úÖ Yes

üí° Pro Tip: Zyada tar production mein teeno use hote hain - they make a SUPER TEAM! ü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü¶∏

üéØ Interview Questions - API Gateway & Proxies

Q: "API Gateway mein rate limiting kaise implement karoge?"

Answer: Multiple algorithms available hain:

  • Token Bucket: Fixed capacity bucket, tokens refill over time - bursty traffic allow karta hai
  • Leaky Bucket: Constant rate pe process - smoother output, queues excess
  • Fixed Window: Per minute/hour limits - simple but edge case issues
  • Sliding Window: Rolling window - more accurate, avoids burst at window edges

Implementation: Redis + Lua scripts for distributed rate limiting (atomic operations)

Q: "Nginx as Reverse Proxy vs dedicated API Gateway - kab kya?"

Answer:

Nginx Use Karo Jab:
  • Simple proxy/load balancing chahiye
  • Static content serving
  • SSL termination
  • Cost constraint hai
API Gateway Use Karo Jab:
  • Advanced auth (OAuth, JWT)
  • Request transformation
  • Developer portal chahiye
  • Analytics & monitoring built-in

Q: "Service Mesh vs API Gateway - difference kya hai?"

Answer:

  • API Gateway: North-South traffic (external clients ‚Üí services), edge pe baitha hai
  • Service Mesh: East-West traffic (service ‚Üî service), sidecar pattern (Istio, Linkerd)
  • Service Mesh provides: mTLS, service discovery, circuit breaker, observability between services
  • Overlap: Dono rate limiting, auth kar sakte hain, but different scopes

Big companies dono use karte hain: API Gateway for external, Service Mesh for internal

HTTP Status Codes - Response Ka Language

üî¢ HTTP Status Codes Categories

HTTP Status Codes = Server ki response language!

3-digit numbers jo batate hain request ka kya hua!

1xx - Informational üìù

Request received, continuing process...

100 Continue | 101 Switching Protocols

2xx - Success ‚úÖ

Request successful ho gayi!

200 OK | 201 Created | 204 No Content

3xx - Redirection üîÄ

Further action chahiye!

301 Moved Permanently | 302 Found | 304 Not Modified

4xx - Client Error ‚ö†Ô∏è

Client ki galti hai!

400 Bad Request | 401 Unauthorized | 404 Not Found

5xx - Server Error üí•

Server ki galti hai!

500 Internal Error | 502 Bad Gateway | 503 Service Unavailable

üéØ Most Common Status Codes:

Code Name Meaning
200 OK Sab theek hai! ‚úÖ
201 Created Resource create ho gaya (POST success)
400 Bad Request Invalid request syntax
401 Unauthorized Authentication chahiye! üîê
403 Forbidden Permission nahi hai! üö´
404 Not Found Resource nahi mila! üîç
500 Internal Server Error Server crash ho gaya! üí•
503 Service Unavailable Server overloaded/maintenance
üí° 401 vs 403 - Kya Farak?

401 Unauthorized: "Tu kaun hai?" - Authentication nahi hai

403 Forbidden: "Tu yehan allowed nahi!" - Authenticated but not authorized

üè∑Ô∏è

Semantic Versioning (SemVer)

üì¶ MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH Format

Semantic Versioning software releases ka ek standard naming convention hai jo developers ko version compatibility samajhne mein help karta hai.

2 . 4 . 1
MAJOR MINOR PATCH
üî¥ MAJOR Version

Breaking Changes!

Jab backward-incompatible changes ho

Old code may break üí•

Example: 1.x.x ‚Üí 2.0.0
API signature change, removed features
üü° MINOR Version

New Features!

Jab backward-compatible features add ho

Old code still works ‚úÖ

Example: 2.3.x ‚Üí 2.4.0
New API endpoints, new methods
üü¢ PATCH Version

Bug Fixes!

Jab backward-compatible bug fixes ho

Safe to update üõ°Ô∏è

Example: 2.4.0 ‚Üí 2.4.1
Security patches, typo fixes

üìù Package.json Version Ranges

Syntax Meaning Allowed Updates
^1.2.3 Caret Range MINOR + PATCH (1.2.3 to <2.0.0)
~1.2.3 Tilde Range PATCH only (1.2.3 to <1.3.0)
1.2.3 Exact Version No updates - exactly this!
* or latest Any Version All versions allowed ‚ö†Ô∏è Risky

üè∑Ô∏è Pre-release Labels

alpha - Very early, unstable (2.0.0-alpha.1)
beta - Feature complete, may have bugs (2.0.0-beta.1)
rc - Release Candidate, almost ready (2.0.0-rc.1)
üí° Best Practices

‚úÖ Production mein ~ use karo - sirf PATCH updates

‚úÖ Dev dependencies mein ^ ok - new features chahiye

‚úÖ Version 0.x.x = unstable, anything can change

‚úÖ Always check CHANGELOG before major update!

IPv4 vs IPv6 - IP Address Evolution

üì° Internet Protocol Versions

IP Address = Internet ka Phone Number! üìû

Har device ko unique identify karne ke liye IP address chahiye

üì¶ IPv4 (Internet Protocol v4)
192.168.1.100
  • Format: 32-bit address
  • Notation: Decimal (dots separated)
  • Example: 192.168.1.100
  • Total Addresses: ~4.3 billion (2¬≥¬≤)
  • Status: Running out! üò∞
üöÄ IPv6 (Internet Protocol v6)
2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334
  • Format: 128-bit address
  • Notation: Hexadecimal (colons)
  • Example: 2001:db8::1
  • Total Addresses: ~340 undecillion (2¬π¬≤‚Å∏)
  • Status: Future ready! üéâ

üìä Detailed Comparison:

Feature IPv4 IPv6
Address Length 32-bit (4 bytes) 128-bit (16 bytes)
Header Size 20-60 bytes 40 bytes (fixed)
Checksum Yes ‚úÖ No (handled by upper layers)
NAT Required? Yes (addresses kam) No (enough addresses)
Security IPSec optional IPSec built-in ‚úÖ
Auto-configuration DHCP required SLAAC (automatic) ‚úÖ
Broadcast Yes No (Multicast instead)

üìè Address Space Comparison:

2¬≥¬≤

‚âà 4.3 Billion IPv4

World population se kam!

2¬π¬≤‚Å∏

340 Undecillion IPv6

Stars in universe se zyada!

üê¢ IPv6 Adoption Slow Kyun?

‚ùå Old devices/routers IPv6 support nahi karte

‚ùå NAT se temporary fix ho gaya IPv4 shortage

‚ùå Migration costly aur complex hai

‚ùå IPv4 aur IPv6 directly compatible nahi

üí° Quick Tip

IPv6 Shorthand: 2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0001

= 2001:db8::1 (zeros compress kar sakte ho!)

REST API Authentication Methods

üîë 4 Popular Auth Methods

API Authentication ensure karta hai ki sirf authorized users ya applications API resources access kar sakein.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Basic Authentication

Username + Password har request mein bhejo

Header: Authorization: Basic base64(user:pass)

‚ö†Ô∏è Only use with HTTPS!

Use: Simple apps, internal APIs

2Ô∏è‚É£ Token Authentication (JWT)

Login pe token milo, har request mein bhejo

Header: Authorization: Bearer <token>

‚úÖ Credentials bar bar nahi bhejne padte

Use: SPAs, Mobile apps, Microservices

3Ô∏è‚É£ OAuth 2.0

Third-party apps ko limited access do without sharing password

Access tokens + Refresh tokens

üîí "Login with Google/Facebook"

Use: Third-party integrations, Social logins

4Ô∏è‚É£ API Key

Unique key assign karo, header/query mein bhejo

Header: X-API-Key: your-api-key

‚ö†Ô∏è Less secure than OAuth/JWT

Use: Public APIs, Rate limiting

SD-Book Ch 1: Scale from Zero to Millions

üéØ Chapter 1 Ka Overview

üöÄ Is chapter me hum ek website ko zero se millions of users tak scale karenge!

Ye chapter Alex Xu ki "System Design Interview" book ka foundation hai. Har concept ko step-by-step samjhenge:

üñ•Ô∏è Single Server

Shuru se web + DB ek hi machine par

üóÑÔ∏è Database Tier

SQL vs NoSQL, separate DB server

‚öñÔ∏è Load Balancer

Traffic distribute karna multiple servers pe

üîÑ DB Replication

Master-Slave setup for reads/writes

‚ö° Cache Layer

In-memory fast storage

üåç CDN

Static content globally serve

üîê Stateless Tier

Session ko external storage me

üè¢ Multi Data Center

GeoDNS + Failover

üñ•Ô∏è Single Server Setup - Journey Shuru!

Har scalable system ki journey ek single server se shuru hoti hai. Imagine karo tumne ek startup shuru kiya - pehle din se multi-region deployment ki zaroorat nahi hai! üòÑ

üèóÔ∏è Figure 1-1: Single Server Setup

flowchart TB subgraph User["üë§ User"] WB["üíª Web browser"] MA["üì± Mobile app"] end DNS(("üåê DNS")) subgraph Server[" "] WS["üñ•Ô∏è Web server"] end User -->|"api.mysite.com"| DNS DNS -->|"IP address"| User User -->|"www.mysite.com"| WS User -->|"api.mysite.com"| WS style DNS fill:#4a90d9,stroke:#357abd,color:#fff style WS fill:#22c55e,stroke:#16a34a,color:#fff style User fill:#2a2a4e,stroke:#4a5568,color:#fff style Server fill:transparent,stroke:#4a5568,stroke-dasharray: 5 5

üì° Request Flow Explained

  1. User browser me type karta hai: www.mysite.com
  2. DNS Lookup: Browser DNS server se IP address mangta hai
  3. DNS Response: DNS server IP return karta hai (jaise 15.125.87.21)
  4. HTTP Request: Browser us IP par HTTP request bhejta hai
  5. Response: Server HTML page ya JSON data return karta hai
‚ö†Ô∏è Single Server Problems:
  • Server down = Website down (Single Point of Failure)
  • High traffic pe slow ho jaata hai
  • Database aur web server same resources share karte hain
  • Scaling possible nahi hai
üì± Web vs Mobile Traffic

Server do tarah ke traffic handle karta hai - Web Browser se aur Mobile Apps se:

üåê Web Browser Traffic

Server-side rendering hota hai. Server poora HTML page generate karke bhejta hai.

Response: HTML/CSS/JS
üì± Mobile App Traffic

API calls hote hain. Server data bhejta hai, rendering app me hoti hai.

Response: JSON Data

üì¶ JSON API Response Example

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "user": {
      "id": 12345,
      "name": "Rahul Sharma",
      "email": "rahul@example.com"
    },
    "posts": [
      { "id": 1, "title": "My First Post" },
      { "id": 2, "title": "System Design Tips" }
    ]
  }
}
üóÑÔ∏è Database Tier - Separate Karna Zaroori!

Jaise traffic badhta hai, web tier (server) aur data tier (database) ko alag-alag servers par separate karna sabse pehla aur sabse important optimization step hai. Isko separate karne se dono tiers ko independently scale kar sakte hain, matlab web servers alag se badhao aur databases alag se badhao - dono ek doosre ko limit nahi karte!

üéØ Core Concept - Web Tier vs Data Tier:

Single server setup mein web server aur database same machine par hote hain, jo ek bottleneck create karta hai. Separation karne se:

  • Web Tier: Handles HTTP requests, business logic, response generation - ye independently scale hota hai (multiple web servers add karo)
  • Data Tier: Handles data storage, retrieval, persistence - ye independently scale hota hai (replicas, sharding add karo)

‚ö†Ô∏è Problem - Single Web Server Offline Ho Jaye To?

Agar sirf ek hi web server hai aur wo crash ho jaye ya offline ho jaye, to users ka koi bhi request handle nahi hoga. Ye Single Point of Failure (SPOF) hai. Iska matlab hai ki poori website/app down ho jayegi jab tak server wapas online nahi aata.

‚ùå Kya Hota Hai:
  • Users ko timeout errors milte hain
  • Website completely unreachable ho jati hai
  • Database accessible hai but koi query nahi aa rahi
  • Revenue loss aur user trust damage
‚úÖ Solution - Failover:
  • Multiple web servers deploy karo
  • Load Balancer add karo jo traffic distribute kare
  • Ek server down ho to doosra handle kare
  • Auto-scaling se demand ke hisaab se servers add/remove ho
üî• Problem - Traffic Spike / Server Overload:

Jab bohot saare users ek hi time pe website access karte hain, to single web server ki CPU, RAM aur network bandwidth limit tak pahunch jati hai. Server slow ho jata hai ya completely crash ho jata hai ‚Äî ye hai scalability problem.

üìä Server Resource Usage

üî≤ CPU Usage 98%
üíæ RAM Usage 95%
üåê Network I/O 92%
‚ö†Ô∏è Kya Hota Hai:
  • Response time seconds se minutes mein badh jata hai
  • Users ko 503 Service Unavailable errors milte hain
  • Database queries queue mein atki reh jati hain
  • Server crash ho sakta hai ‚Äî sab users affected
  • Peak hours mein (sales, events) problem aur bhi worse
‚úÖ Solution - Horizontal Scaling:
  • Load Balancer add karo ‚Äî traffic multiple servers pe distribute ho
  • Horizontal Scaling ‚Äî zyada servers add karo (scale out)
  • Auto-scaling ‚Äî traffic ke hisaab se automatically servers add/remove
  • CDN + Caching ‚Äî static content cache karo, server load kam ho
  • Database replicas ‚Äî read queries distribute karo
üí° Separation Ka Biggest Benefit:

Web tier aur data tier ko separate karne se dono ko independently scale kar sakte hain. Agar web traffic zyada hai to sirf web servers add karo. Agar database slow hai to sirf database optimize karo (replicas, sharding, caching). Ye flexibility single server architecture mein bilkul nahi milti!

‚öîÔ∏è SQL vs NoSQL - Kab Kya Use Karein?

Database choose karna ek critical decision hai. Book ke according, tum relational databases (SQL) ya non-relational databases (NoSQL) mein se choose kar sakte ho. Dono ke apne strengths aur use cases hain.

üîµ Relational Databases (RDBMS)

MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server

Relational databases data ko tables aur rows mein represent karte hain. Tum different tables ke data par SQL language use karke JOIN operations perform kar sakte ho.

  • Data structured hai (tables, rows, columns mein organized)
  • ACID transactions support karta hai (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability)
  • Complex JOINs perform kar sakte ho across multiple tables
  • Data relationships clearly defined hain (foreign keys, constraints)
  • 40+ saal se proven technology hai - most popular choice
Best for: Banking, E-commerce, ERP, Traditional web apps, Inventory management
üü† Non-Relational Databases (NoSQL)

MongoDB, CouchDB, Cassandra, DynamoDB, Neo4j, HBase

NoSQL databases ko 4 major categories mein divide kiya jata hai. Ye databases JOIN operations generally support nahi karte.

  • Super low latency requirements ke liye best
  • Unstructured ya semi-structured data store karna ho
  • Massive amounts of data (petabytes) handle karna ho
  • JOINs ki zaroorat nahi hoti - denormalized data
  • Schema flexibility chahiye (data structure change ho sakti hai)
Best for: Social media, IoT, Real-time analytics, Caching, Session management

üì¶ NoSQL Ke 4 Major Types

üîë Key-Value Stores

Data ko simple key-value pairs mein store karta hai. Fastest lookups!

key: "user:123" ‚Üí value: "{name, age...}"

Examples: Redis, DynamoDB, Memcached

üîó Graph Stores

Data ko nodes aur edges (relationships) mein store karta hai. Best for relationship-heavy data!

(User A) --follows--> (User B)

Examples: Neo4j, Amazon Neptune

üìä Column Stores

Data ko columns mein group karke store karta hai instead of rows. Best for analytics!

column_family: {row_key ‚Üí {col1, col2...}}

Examples: Cassandra, HBase

üìÑ Document Stores

Data ko JSON/BSON documents mein store karta hai. Flexible schema!

{"_id": 1, "name": "Kundan", "skills": [...]}

Examples: MongoDB, CouchDB

‚ö†Ô∏è NoSQL Kab Use Karna Chahiye? (Book Ki 4 Conditions)

Book ke according, NoSQL tab right choice ho sakta hai jab tumhari application ko in mein se koi bhi condition match kare:

‚ë† Tumhari application ko super-low latency chahiye, matlab response time extremely fast hona chahiye.
‚ë° Tumhara data unstructured hai, ya tumhare paas koi relational data nahi hai jo tables mein fit ho sake.
‚ë¢ Tumhe sirf data ko serialize aur deserialize karna hai (JSON, XML, YAML, etc.), complex queries nahi chahiye.
‚ë£ Tumhe massive amount of data store karna hai jo traditional RDBMS ki capacity se zyada hai.
üí° Pro Tip: Most applications ke liye relational databases (SQL) best choice hain kyunki structured data aur ACID transactions important hote hain. NoSQL tab use karo jab tumhari specific requirements match karein - jaise high write throughput, flexible schema, ya massive scale. Galat database choose karna ek costly mistake hai!
üéØ Interview Mein Aise Bolo:

"Web tier aur data tier ko separate karna is design ka first step hai. Isse dono tiers independently scale ho sakte hain. Database selection context-dependent hai - relational databases tabse best hain jab data structured ho aur ACID transactions zaroori hain, jabki NoSQL tab prefer karte hain jab super-low latency, massive scale, ya flexible schema ki requirement ho."

üìà Vertical vs Horizontal Scaling

Traffic badhe to do tarike se handle kar sakte hain - bigger machine ya more machines!

‚¨ÜÔ∏è Vertical Scaling (Scale Up)

"Add more power to existing server"

üñ•Ô∏è
‚¨áÔ∏è
üñ•Ô∏è

‚úÖ Simple implementation

‚úÖ No code changes

‚ùå Hardware limit hai

‚ùå Single point of failure

‚ùå Expensive (exponential cost)

‚û°Ô∏è Horizontal Scaling (Scale Out)

"Add more servers"

üñ•Ô∏è
‚¨áÔ∏è
üñ•Ô∏è
üñ•Ô∏è
üñ•Ô∏è

‚úÖ No hardware limit

‚úÖ Failover possible

‚úÖ Cost effective (commodity HW)

‚ùå Complex architecture

‚ùå Data consistency challenges

üéØ Interview Answer: "Large scale applications horizontal scaling prefer karti hain kyunki vertical scaling ki physical limit hoti hai. Vertical scaling ek point ke baad possible nahi hota, jabki horizontal scaling me unlimited servers add kar sakte hain."
‚öñÔ∏è Load Balancer - Traffic Distribution Ka King! üëë

Load Balancer ek aisa device ya software hai jo user aur server group ke beech baithta hai aur incoming traffic ko multiple servers me intelligently distribute karta hai. Socho jaise restaurant me manager customers ko different waiters ko assign karta hai ‚Äî same concept!

üçΩÔ∏è Restaurant Analogy:

Agar customers apne waiters khud choose karein, to kuch waiters overloaded ho jayenge aur baaki idle! Manager (Load Balancer) ensure karta hai ki sab waiters equally busy rahein aur customers ko best service mile.

üîÑ Failover in Action - Server 1 Goes Offline!

Figure 1-4b: Load Balancer Failover ‚Äî Server 1 Offline, Traffic Rerouted to Server 2

‚è±Ô∏è Failover Process ‚Äî Step by Step

1 LB har 5-10 seconds mein Server 1 aur Server 2 ko health check ping bhejta hai
2 Server 1 respond nahi karta ‚Äî LB 2-3 retries karta hai to confirm
3 Server 1 ko unhealthy mark karta hai ‚Äî server pool se remove kar deta hai
4 Saara traffic Server 2 pe reroute ‚Äî users ko koi downtime feel nahi hoti ‚úÖ
5 Jab Server 1 wapas online aaye, LB health check pass hone pe usse pool mein add kar deta hai
üîç Health Check Types:
  • TCP Check: Server ke port pe connection try karo
  • HTTP Check: /health endpoint pe GET request bhejo
  • Custom Check: Specific API call karke app status verify karo
‚úÖ Without vs With Load Balancer:
  • Without LB: Server down = website down ‚ùå
  • With LB: Server down = traffic rerouted, zero downtime ‚úÖ
  • Ye hai High Availability ka magic! ü™Ñ
üìà Horizontal Scaling ‚Äî Traffic Badha? Simply Ek Aur Server Add Karo!

Jab traffic badhne lage aur existing 2 servers load handle nahi kar pa rahe, to developer simply ek naya Server 3 add karta hai. Load Balancer automatically detect karta hai naya server aur traffic ko teeno servers mein equally distribute kar deta hai. Koi downtime nahi, koi disruption nahi ‚Äî ye hai Horizontal Scaling (Scale Out) ka power! üí™

Server 1 CPU 35%

üîß Developer Kya Karta Hai:
  • Naya server provision karo (same config)
  • App deploy karo naye server pe
  • Server ko LB ke server pool mein register karo
  • LB health check pass hone pe traffic bhejta hai
  • Zero downtime ‚Äî existing users ko koi impact nahi!
ü§ñ Auto-Scaling (Cloud Magic):
  • Cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP) ye automatically karte hain
  • Rule set karo: "CPU > 70% ho to naya server add karo"
  • Traffic kam ho to extra servers remove ho jate hain (cost saving üí∞)
  • Ye hai Elastic Scaling ‚Äî demand ke hisaab se grow/shrink

üîë Key Concepts

  • Public IP: Load balancer ka IP jo users ko dikhta hai (internet-facing)
  • Private IP: Servers ke internal IPs, directly accessible nahi (security ke liye)
  • Health Checks: LB regularly servers ko ping karta hai to check if they're alive
  • Failover: Agar ek server down, traffic automatically dusre healthy server ko redirect

üßÆ Load Balancing Algorithms - Kaunsa Method Use Karein?

Load balancer ko decide karna padta hai ki kaun si request kis server ko jaaye. Ye decision different algorithms se hota hai:

üìä Static Load Balancing (Fixed Rules)

Ye algorithms server ki current state nahi dekhte ‚Äî predefined rules follow karte hain.

üîÑ Round Robin

Requests ko turn by turn different servers ko bhejta hai. Simple hai but assumes all servers equal capacity ke hain.

Server 1 ‚Üí Server 2 ‚Üí Server 3 ‚Üí Server 1...

‚öñÔ∏è Weighted Round Robin

Powerful servers ko zyada weight assign karo! Wo zyada requests handle karenge.

Server A (weight:3) gets 3x traffic vs Server B (weight:1)

#Ô∏è‚É£ IP Hash

Client IP ka hash calculate karo aur same client hamesha same server pe jaaye. Session persistence ke liye useful!

hash(client_ip) % num_servers = target_server

‚ö° Dynamic Load Balancing (Smart Decisions)

Ye algorithms real-time server state check karke intelligent decisions lete hain!

üîó Least Connections

Jis server pe sabse kam active connections hain, usse request bhejo! Smart hai kyunki busy server pe load nahi badhata.

Best for: Long-lived connections (WebSocket, DB)

‚è±Ô∏è Least Response Time

Jo server sabse fast respond kar raha hai, usse bhejo! Response time + active connections dono consider karta hai.

Best for: Optimal user experience

üìä Resource-Based

Server pe agent chalta hai jo CPU, memory usage report karta hai. LB sirf unhe traffic bhejta hai jinke paas resources free hain!

Best for: Heterogeneous server environments

üè∑Ô∏è Types of Load Balancers - Layer 4 vs Layer 7

üîå Layer 4 (Network/Transport)

TCP/UDP level pe kaam karta hai. IP address aur port dekh ke routing decision leta hai. Content nahi padh sakta.

  • Fast hai (no content inspection)
  • Simple configuration
  • Protocol agnostic

Use: High-performance TCP/UDP load balancing

üåê Layer 7 (Application)

HTTP/HTTPS level pe kaam karta hai. URL, headers, cookies, SSL sab padh sakta hai. Smart routing possible!

  • Content-based routing (URL paths)
  • SSL termination
  • A/B testing, canary deployments

Use: Web apps, microservices routing

üõ†Ô∏è Popular Load Balancing Solutions

üü¢
NGINX

Software LB, very popular

üî¥
HAProxy

High-performance, reliable

‚òÅÔ∏è
AWS ELB/ALB

Managed, auto-scaling

üîµ
Azure LB

Microsoft cloud native

‚úÖ Load Balancer Benefits Summary:
  • High Availability: Server down? Traffic automatically redirect ho jaata hai
  • Scalability: Easily add/remove servers bina downtime ke
  • Performance: Traffic evenly distribute = better response times
  • Security: Servers private network me, DDoS protection, SSL termination
  • Flexibility: Maintenance aur upgrades bina downtime ke
üéØ Interview Answer:

"Load Balancer ek critical component hai jo traffic ko multiple servers me distribute karta hai. Ye availability improve karta hai (failover support), scalability enable karta hai (add more servers), aur security enhance karta hai (servers private network me). Different algorithms jaise Round Robin, Least Connections ya IP Hash use hote hain based on use case."

üîÑ Database Replication - Master/Slave Architecture Ka Deep Dive üî•

Ab web tier to fault tolerant ho gaya, but database abhi bhi single point of failure hai! Isko solve karne ke liye database replication use hota hai.

üìñ Definition:

Database Replication ka matlab hai original database (master) ki copies (slaves) banana taaki data multiple locations pe available rahe. Ye technique read performance, reliability, aur availability sabhi improve karti hai!

flowchart TB subgraph WebServers["üñ•Ô∏è Web Servers"] WS1["Server 1"] WS2["Server 2"] WS3["Server 3"] end MasterDB[("üóÑÔ∏è Master DB
(writes)")] subgraph Slaves["Slave Databases (reads)"] Slave1[("üóÑÔ∏è Slave DB1")] Slave2[("üóÑÔ∏è Slave DB2")] Slave3[("üóÑÔ∏è Slave DB3")] end WebServers -->|"writes"| MasterDB WebServers -->|"reads"| Slave1 WebServers -->|"reads"| Slave2 WebServers -->|"reads"| Slave3 MasterDB -->|"DB replication"| Slave1 MasterDB -->|"DB replication"| Slave2 MasterDB -->|"DB replication"| Slave3 style MasterDB fill:#3b82f6,stroke:#1d4ed8,color:#fff style Slave1 fill:#3b82f6,stroke:#1d4ed8,color:#fff style Slave2 fill:#3b82f6,stroke:#1d4ed8,color:#fff style Slave3 fill:#3b82f6,stroke:#1d4ed8,color:#fff style WS1 fill:#22c55e,stroke:#16a34a,color:#fff style WS2 fill:#22c55e,stroke:#16a34a,color:#fff style WS3 fill:#22c55e,stroke:#16a34a,color:#fff style WebServers fill:transparent,stroke:#4a5568,stroke-dasharray: 5 5 style Slaves fill:transparent,stroke:#4a5568,stroke-dasharray: 5 5

Figure 1-5

üéØ Master-Slave Working

  • Master: Sabhi write operations (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE) sirf master handle karta hai
  • Slaves: Sabhi read operations. Read traffic bahut zyada hota hai, isliye multiple slaves
  • Replication: Master apna data automatically slaves ko replicate karta hai
  • Read:Write Ratio: Most apps me 90% reads, 10% writes hote hain

üèóÔ∏è Figure 1-6: Complete Design with LB + DB Replication

flowchart TB subgraph User["üë§ User"] WB["üíª Web browser"] MA["üì± Mobile app"] end DNS(("üåê DNS
IP address")) LB["‚öñÔ∏è Load Balancer"] subgraph WebTier["Web Tier"] S1["üñ•Ô∏è Server 1"] S2["üñ•Ô∏è Server 2"] end subgraph DataTier["Data Tier"] MasterDB[("üóÑÔ∏è Master DB")] SlaveDB[("üóÑÔ∏è Slave DB")] end User -->|"www.mysite.com"| DNS DNS --> User User --> LB LB --> S1 LB --> S2 S1 -->|"Write"| MasterDB S2 -->|"Write"| MasterDB S1 -->|"Read"| SlaveDB S2 -->|"Read"| SlaveDB MasterDB -->|"Replicate"| SlaveDB style DNS fill:#4a90d9,stroke:#357abd,color:#fff style LB fill:#00bcd4,stroke:#0097a7,color:#fff style S1 fill:#22c55e,stroke:#16a34a,color:#fff style S2 fill:#22c55e,stroke:#16a34a,color:#fff style MasterDB fill:#3b82f6,stroke:#1d4ed8,color:#fff style SlaveDB fill:#3b82f6,stroke:#1d4ed8,color:#fff style User fill:#2a2a4e,stroke:#4a5568,color:#fff style WebTier fill:transparent,stroke:#4a5568,stroke-dasharray: 5 5 style DataTier fill:transparent,stroke:#4a5568,stroke-dasharray: 5 5

Figure 1-6

üìã Figure 1-6 Design Summary

  • A user gets the IP address of the load balancer from DNS.
  • A user connects to the load balancer with this IP address.
  • The HTTP request is routed to either Server 1 or Server 2.
  • A web server reads user data from a slave database.
  • A web server routes any data-modifying operations to the master database. This includes write, update, and delete operations.

‚ö†Ô∏è Failure Scenarios - Production Reality!

üìñ Slave Fails:

Read traffic remaining healthy slaves pe redirect ho jaata hai. New slave add karke cluster ko recover kar sakte hain. No data loss!

üëë Master Fails (Complex!):

Ek slave promote hokar new master ban jaata hai. But ye simple nahi hai ‚Äî slave ka data outdated ho sakta hai (replication lag). Data recovery scripts chalane padte hain!

üîÑ Replication Types - Synchronous vs Asynchronous

Replication do tarike se ho sakti hai ‚Äî dono ke apne trade-offs hain:

‚úÖ Synchronous Replication

Master wait karta hai jab tak slave acknowledge nahi karta ki data receive ho gaya. Write tabhi complete hota hai!

  • ‚úì Strong consistency guaranteed
  • ‚úì Zero data loss possible
  • ‚úó Slower writes (latency adds up)
  • ‚úó Slave down = writes blocked!

Use: Banking, financial systems (data accuracy critical)

‚ö° Asynchronous Replication

Master immediately return karta hai, slaves ko data background me milta hai (eventually consistent).

  • ‚úì Fast writes
  • ‚úì Slave failure doesn't block master
  • ‚úó Replication lag possible
  • ‚úó Data loss risk in master failure

Use: Social media, e-commerce (performance > perfect consistency)

üèÜ Database Replication Ke 3 Major Benefits

üöÄ Better Performance

Writes sirf master pe, but reads multiple slaves pe parallel process ho sakte hain. Read throughput dramatically increase hota hai!

üîí Reliability

Data multiple locations pe replicated hai. Natural disaster (earthquake, typhoon) bhi data destroy nahi kar sakta ‚Äî copies safe hain!

üåê High Availability

Ek database offline? Dusre servers se data access possible! Website operational rehti hai even during partial failures.

üéØ Interview Pro Tip:

"Master-Slave replication read-heavy workloads ke liye ideal hai (most apps 90% reads, 10% writes). Master failover complex hai ‚Äî production systems use automatic failover tools like MySQL MHA, PostgreSQL Patroni, etc. Replication lag handle karna important hai for eventual consistency!"

‚ö°

Cache & CDN - Speed Boost!

üß† Cache Kyun Zaroori Hai? - The "WHY" Behind Caching

Ab tak tumne web tier aur data tier kaafi clearly samajh liya hai. Next obvious problem ye aati hai ki response time aur load kaise improve karein.

Socho jaise-jaise traffic badhta hai, har request ke liye database call karna bahut mehenga ho jaata hai. Database disk-based hota hai, slow hota hai, aur high concurrency pe jaldi choke kar jata hai. Is problem ka sabse practical solution hota hai cache add karna aur static content ko CDN par shift karna.

üö´ Problem without Cache - Real Scenario:

Imagine karo tumhari e-commerce site par 10,000 users ek hi product page dekh rahe hain. Agar har user ke liye database call hogi:

  • Har request ke liye database call = expensive! (10,000 DB queries üò±)
  • Database disk-based hota hai = slow (50-100ms per query)
  • High concurrency pe database choke kar jaata hai (connection pool exhausted)
  • Response time badhta jaata hai (users frustrated!)

üí° Cache Kya Hota Hai? - The Concept

Cache ek temporary storage hota hai jo memory (RAM) me hota hai aur expensive operations ke results ko store karta hai.

Expensive ka matlab kya hai?

  • üóÑÔ∏è Database queries jo slow hain
  • üî¢ Heavy computations (complex calculations)
  • üîÑ Frequently accessed data jo baar-baar manga ja raha hai
  • üåê External API calls jo latency add karte hain

Jab ek hi data baar-baar manga ja raha ho, to har baar database ko hit karna bilkul inefficient hai. Cache ye problem solve karta hai by storing frequently accessed data in memory, jisse next request ka response bahut fast ho jaata hai.

üìä Cache vs Database - Speed Comparison
üóÑÔ∏è
Database Query

50-100ms

Disk I/O + Network

‚ö°
Cache Lookup

< 1ms

In-Memory (RAM)

‚ö° Cache is 50-100x FASTER than Database!

üèóÔ∏è Figure 1-7: Cache Tier Setup

Cache tier ka matlab hota hai database se alag ek dedicated fast layer jo sirf caching ke liye hoti hai. Ye database se kaafi zyada fast hoti hai, kyunki ye RAM based hoti hai.

üéØ Cache Tier Benefits:
  • Database ka load kam hota hai (80-90% requests cache se serve)
  • Overall system dramatically fast hota hai
  • Cache ko independently scale kar sakte ho
  • Database failure ke time bhi cached data available rehta hai
%%{init: {'theme': 'dark', 'themeVariables': { 'primaryColor': '#22c55e', 'secondaryColor': '#ffd93d', 'tertiaryColor': '#3b82f6', 'primaryTextColor': '#fff', 'lineColor': '#00bcd4', 'fontSize': '14px'}}}%% graph LR subgraph " " WS[üñ•Ô∏è Web server] C[üì¶ CACHE] DB[(üóÑÔ∏è Database)] end WS -->|"1. If data exists in cache,
read data from cache"| C C -->|"2.2 Return data to
the web server"| WS C -.->|"2.1 If data doesn't exist

Figure 1-7

üîÑ Read-Through Cache Strategy - Step by Step

Is approach ko read-through cache bola jaata hai. Matlab application ke perspective se wo sirf cache se baat kar raha hota hai. Cache internally decide karta hai ki data available hai ya database se laana hai.

üîÑ Complete Flow (Figure 1-7 Explained):

  1. Web server request receive karta hai (e.g., GET /user/123)
  2. Pehle cache check karta hai - "Kya user 123 ka data cache me hai?"
  3. Agar data mil gaya (Cache HIT ‚úÖ) ‚Üí Direct return (< 1ms!)
  4. Agar nahi mila (Cache MISS ‚ùå) ‚Üí Database se fetch karo
  5. Cache me store karo for future requests (SET user:123 with TTL)
  6. Client ko response do

Ye strategy simple hoti hai aur kaafi common hai, lekin data type, size aur access pattern ke hisaab se aur bhi caching strategies hoti hain:

üéØ Caching Strategies - Kaunsi Strategy Kab Use Karein?

üìñ Cache-Aside (Lazy Loading)

Application khud manage karti hai cache aur DB dono ko. Data cache me nahi? DB se lao, cache me daalo.

data = cache.get(key)
if not data:
  data = db.query(key)
  cache.set(key, data, ttl)

‚úÖ Best for: Read-heavy workloads, unpredictable access patterns

‚úèÔ∏è Write-Through

Data pehle cache me write hota hai, phir synchronously DB me. Cache hamesha fresh!

cache.set(key, data)
db.write(key, data) # sync

‚úÖ Best for: Strong consistency needed, data frequently read after write

‚ö° Write-Behind (Write-Back)

Data sirf cache me write hota hai initially. DB me asynchronously batch me jaata hai!

cache.set(key, data)
# async batch write to DB
queue.push(key, data)

‚úÖ Best for: Write-heavy workloads, analytics, logs (eventual consistency OK)

üìö Read-Through

Cache khud DB se fetch karta hai when miss hota hai. Application sirf cache se baat karti hai!

data = cache.get(key)
# Cache internally fetches
# from DB if miss

‚úÖ Best for: Simplifying application code, consistent data access pattern

‚ö†Ô∏è Cache Considerations - Important Points!

‚è∞ Expiration Policy (TTL)

Data kab expire hoga? TTL (Time To Live) set karo. Too short = baar-baar DB calls. Too long = stale data serve hoga.

üîÑ Consistency

Cache aur DB me data sync kaise rahega? Data update hone par cache invalidate karo ya update karo.

üí• Eviction Policy

Cache full ho jaaye to kya hatana hai? LRU (Least Recently Used), LFU (Least Frequently Used), FIFO etc.

üîí Single Point of Failure

Agar cache server down ho jaaye? Multiple cache servers use karo ya Redis Cluster setup karo.

üí° Cache Benefits Summary:

‚úÖ Response time dramatically improve hota hai (ms instead of seconds)

‚úÖ Database load 80-90% tak kam ho sakta hai

‚úÖ Cache ko independently scale kar sakte ho

‚úÖ Cost effective - same hardware, better performance

üåç CDN - Content Delivery Network Ka Complete Deep Dive! üöÄ

Ab cache ke baad next optimization hoti hai CDN (Content Delivery Network). CDN ek network hai geographically dispersed servers ka jo users ke nearest location se static content serve karta hai!

üìñ CDN Ka Primary Purpose:

Latency reduce karna! Internet ki complex nature ki wajah se client aur server ke beech communication me physical distance matters. CDN intermediary servers introduce karke is delay ko minimize karta hai.

Simple language me samjho: Jo user CDN server ke jitna paas hota hai, usko utni fast website milti hai. Jaise agar CDN server San Francisco me hai, to Los Angeles ke users ko Europe ke users ke comparison me zyada fast content milega.

Agar user India me hai aur origin server US me, to har request me latency high hogi (~120ms). CDN is latency ko kaafi reduce kar deta hai (~30ms)!

üèÜ CDN Ke 4 Major Benefits

‚ö° Page Load Time ‚Üì

Website slow? Users bounce! CDN se content nearby servers se serve hota hai resulting in faster page loads aur better user experience.

üí∞ Bandwidth Cost ‚Üì

Every request consumes bandwidth = cost! CDN caching aur optimizations se origin server se data transfer kam hota hai = lower hosting bills!

üåê Content Availability ‚Üë

Traffic spike? Hardware failure? CDN distributed hai ‚Äî ek server down bhi ho to dusre servers content serve karte rahenge!

üîí Security Enhanced

DDoS attacks me attackers millions of fake requests bhejte hain. CDN in attacks ko distribute karke absorb kar leta hai ‚Äî origin server safe!

üì¶ Static vs Dynamic Content

‚úÖ Static Content (CDN Perfect!)

Data jo user se user change nahi hota. Same file serve hoti hai sabko!

üìú JS/CSS üñºÔ∏è Images üé• Videos üìÑ PDFs üî§ Fonts
‚ö° Dynamic Content (Tricky!)

Data jo user, location, time ke basis pe change hota hai. Traditional caching nahi chalti!

üì∞ News Feeds üå§Ô∏è Weather üîê Login Status üí¨ Chat

‚öôÔ∏è CDN Kaise Kaam Karta Hai? - 3 Key Mechanisms

üì¶ 1. Caching

Static content ki copies store karti hai CDN edge servers pe. First request origin se, baaki requests cache se instant!

‚ö° 2. Dynamic Acceleration

Dynamic content ke liye CDN-to-origin ke beech optimized connections maintain karti hai ‚Äî intelligent routing, already-open connections!

üß† 3. Edge Logic

CDN edge servers pe custom logic run kar sakte ho ‚Äî request validation, content modification, A/B testing, etc. Origin load kam!

üìä Figure 1-9: How CDN Improves Load Time

‚ö†Ô∏è CDN Ke Important Considerations

CDN free nahi hota! Ye third-party services hoti hain aur data transfer ke liye charge karti hain. Isliye smart decisions lena zaroori hai:

üí∞ Cost Optimization:

Agar koi asset rarely access hota hai, to usko CDN pe rakhna useless cost create karta hai. Sirf frequently accessed static content CDN par rakhna chahiye!

‚è∞ TTL Setting - Critical Decision:

TTL bahut zyada = stale/outdated content serve hoga. TTL bahut kam = CDN baar-baar origin fetch karega (latency + cost ‚Üë). Balance bahut carefully choose karo!

üîÑ CDN Fallback Strategy:

Agar CDN temporary down ho jaaye, to client ko origin server se directly content fetch kar paana chahiye. Graceful degradation implement karo!

üîÑ Cache Invalidation:

Content update hone par CDN cache ko kaise invalidate karoge? Version-based URLs (image.png?v=2) ya cache purge API use karo.

üèóÔ∏è Figure 1-11: Design After Cache & CDN Are Added

  2. Database load is lightened by caching data - most reads from cache!
üîê

Stateless Web Tier - The Key to Horizontal Scaling!

üí° Stateless Web Tier Ka Concept - Kyun Zaroori Hai?

Ab next major architectural shift hota hai stateless web tier. Horizontal scaling ke liye ye sabse critical concept hai!

Iska idea ye hai ki web servers ke andar koi user-specific state store nahi honi chahiye, jaise session data, shopping cart, user preferences etc. Session data ko persistent storage me move kar diya jaata hai ‚Äî relational DB, NoSQL, Redis, etc.

üéØ Golden Rule:

Jab web servers stateless ho jaate hain, to cluster ka koi bhi server kisi bhi user ki request handle kar sakta hai. Ye auto-scaling ko extremely easy bana deta hai!

‚ö†Ô∏è Stateful Architecture Ki Problem - Real Scenario

Stateful server ka matlab hota hai server client ka state (jaise session data) yaad rakhta hai. Example: User A login karta hai Server 1 pe, to uska session Server 1 ki memory me store ho jaata hai.

Is design me load balancer ko ensure karna padta hai ki User A hamesha Server 1 pe hi jaaye. Isko sticky sessions bolte hain.

üìä Figure 1-12: Stateful Architecture (Problematic ‚ùå)

%%{init: {'theme': 'dark', 'themeVariables': { 'primaryColor': '#ff6b6b', 'primaryTextColor': '#fff', 'lineColor': '#ff6b6b'}}}%% graph TB UA[üë§ User A] -->|"Must go to Server 1"| S1 UB[üë§ User B] -->|"Must go to Server 2"| S2 UC[üë§ User C] -->|"Must go to Server 3"| S3 subgraph Servers["‚ùå Stateful Servers - Each stores session"] S1["üñ•Ô∏è Server 1
üì¶ User A's Session"] S2["üñ•Ô∏è Server 2
üì¶ User B's Session"] S3["üñ•Ô∏è Server 3
üì¶ User C's Session"] end style UA fill:#667eea,stroke:#5a67d8,color:#fff style UB fill:#a855f7,stroke:#9333ea,color:#fff style UC fill:#00bcd4,stroke:#0097a7,color:#fff style S1 fill:#ff6b6b33,stroke:#ff6b6b,color:#fff style S2 fill:#ff6b6b33,stroke:#ff6b6b,color:#fff style S3 fill:#ff6b6b33,stroke:#ff6b6b,color:#fff

‚ö†Ô∏è Problem: User A's next request MUST go to Server 1! Otherwise, session data will be lost!

Figure 1-12

üö´ Stateful Architecture Problems - In Detail:
  • Sticky Sessions Required: User A hamesha Server 1 pe hi jaana chahiye, warna session lost!
  • Server Fail = Session Lost: Server 1 down ho gaya? User A ka poora session gaya! User ko dobara login karna padega üò§
  • Scaling Difficult: New server add karna complex ho jaata hai - kisko kahan route karna hai?
  • Uneven Load: Kuch servers overloaded ho sakte hain, kuch idle - load balancing inefficient!
  • Server Add/Remove Complex: Traffic redistribution bahut mushkil ho jaati hai
‚úÖ Stateless Architecture - The Elegant Solution!

Stateless architecture me servers ke andar koi user-specific state store nahi hoti. Session data ko shared persistent storage me move kar diya jaata hai!

How it works: Web server request aate hi shared storage se session data fetch karta hai, process karta hai, aur response de deta hai. Server khud kuch remember nahi karta!

üìä Figure 1-13: Stateless Architecture (Recommended ‚úÖ)

%%{init: {'theme': 'dark', 'themeVariables': { 'primaryColor': '#00ff88', 'primaryTextColor': '#fff', 'lineColor': '#00ff88'}}}%% graph TB UA[üë§ User A] --> WebTier UB[üë§ User B] --> WebTier UC[üë§ User C] --> WebTier subgraph WebTier["‚úÖ Stateless Web Tier - Any server can handle any request"] S1[üñ•Ô∏è Server 1] S2[üñ•Ô∏è Server 2] S3[üñ•Ô∏è Server 3] end S1 & S2 & S3 -->|"Fetch session"| Store Store[("üíæ Shared Data Store

‚úÖ Benefit: Any request from any user can be routed to ANY server! Session data is fetched from shared store on demand.

Figure 1-13

‚úÖ Stateless Benefits - Why It's Production Ready:
  • Any server can handle any request - no sticky sessions needed! Simple round-robin LB works!
  • Easy auto-scaling: Traffic badha? New servers add karo. Traffic kam hua? Servers remove karo. Koi complexity nahi!
  • Fault tolerant: Server 1 fail ho gaya? No problem, Server 2 ya 3 immediately handle kar lenge!
  • Simple load balancing: Round-robin works perfectly, no intelligent routing needed
  • Cloud-native: AWS Auto Scaling, Kubernetes HPA - sab seamlessly work karte hain!

üíæ Session Storage Options - Kya Use Karein?

üî¥
Redis

In-memory, super fast, persistence option available. Most popular choice!

üìó
Memcached

Simple, fast, distributed caching. No persistence, pure cache.

üóÑÔ∏è
NoSQL DB

MongoDB, DynamoDB for durability + flexibility

üêò
PostgreSQL

Session table in RDBMS - simpler setup, slower

üéØ Updated Stateless Design Impact:

Is stage par tumhara architecture kaafi mature ho gaya:

  • ‚úÖ User request load balancer ke through kisi bhi server par ja sakti hai
  • ‚úÖ Web servers auto-scale ho rahe hain (up/down based on traffic)
  • ‚úÖ Session data centralized storage me hai (Redis/NoSQL)
  • ‚úÖ CDN static content handle kar raha hai
  • ‚úÖ Cache database load kam kar raha hai
  • ‚úÖ Ye ek production-ready, cloud-native architecture ban gaya!

üìä Figure 1-14: Updated Design with Stateless Web Tier

üè¢

Multiple Data Centers - Going Global! üåç

üåç Multiple Data Centers Ki Need - Kyun Zaroori Hai?

Jaise hi website global scale par grow karti hai, ek single data center sufficient nahi hota!

Socho tumhari website US me hosted hai, lekin India, Europe, Australia me bhi users hain. Agar sab users US data center se data fetch karenge:

üáÆüá≥

India User

~300ms

Latency to US

üá™üá∫

Europe User

~150ms

Latency to US

üá∫üá∏

US User

~20ms

Local DC

Global users ke liye latency kam karne aur availability improve karne ke liye multiple data centers chahiye hote hain!

üåê GeoDNS Ka Role

Is setup me GeoDNS use hota hai, jo user ke location ke basis par nearest data center ka IP return karta hai. Ye intelligent DNS routing hai!

‚ö†Ô∏è Multi-Data-Center Challenges - Real Problems!

Multi-DC setup powerful hai, but bahut complex bhi hai. In challenges ko samajhna zaroori hai:

üö¶ Traffic Redirection

Sabse badi problem! GeoDNS ko sahi configure karna padta hai. DNS propagation time bhi consider karna padta hai (can take minutes to hours).

üîÑ Data Synchronization

Doosri badi problem! Different regions me alag databases aur caches hote hain. Failover ke time data consistency ensure karna kaafi complex hai. Replication lag se stale data serve ho sakta hai.

üß™ Testing & Deployment

Multi-region deployment aur testing complex ho jaata hai. CI/CD pipelines ko multi-DC support karna padta hai. Chaos engineering important ho jaati hai.

üí∞ Cost

Multiple data centers = multiple times cost. Infrastructure, bandwidth, data transfer between regions - sab expensive hai!

üèÜ Chapter 1 Complete Architecture - Final Picture!

üéâ Congratulations! Ab tumhara system production-ready, cloud-native architecture ban gaya!

Cache + CDN ke baad system ka impact dekho:

  • ‚úÖ Static assets web servers se completely nikal gaye ‚Üí CDN handle kar raha hai
  • ‚úÖ Database ka load kaafi kam ho gaya ‚Üí Cache 80-90% reads handle kar raha hai
  • ‚úÖ Overall response time noticeably improve ho gaya
  • ‚úÖ System highly available ‚Üí Multi-DC failover ready
  • ‚úÖ Auto-scaling ready ‚Üí Stateless web tier
